content.p: Where do you find cells that produce enzymes for carbohydrate digestion in the gastrointestinal tract lumen?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The mouth cavity tissue itself only produces mucus.
Correct. The cells lining the mouth cavity only produce mucus.

part.hint: Look at the various enzymes and their sources in The Digestive Enzymes table; you need to compare different locations acting on similar organic substrates.

response.feedback: Correct. Salivary glands produce amylase that begins starch digestion in the mouth.
Incorrect. The enzyme amylase is in saliva, which begins starch digestion in the mouth.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The stomach cells don’t produce any enzymes for carbohydrate digestion, and the acid of the gastric juice destroys those enzymes arriving from the mouth.
Correct. The stomach produces enzymes, but not for carbohydrates; in fact, the low pH of the stomach destroys the salivary amylase so carbohydrate digestion stops here.

response.feedback: Correct. The brush-border cells of the intestinal villi produce a variety of enzymes that break carbohydrates down to monosaccharides at the surface of the tissue.
Incorrect. Brush border cells of the villi do produce enzymes for carbohydrates.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The hepatocytes don’t secrete any carbohydrate enzymes into the gastrointestinal tract, although the liver cells do produce enzymes for carbohydrate metabolism within the liver.
Correct. The contribution of the liver to digestion is bile that is not an enzyme but a chemical that emulsifies lipids.

response.feedback: Correct. The acini cells of the pancreas produce pancreatic amylase in the pancreatic juice, continuing the digestion of starch not completed from the salivary amylase.

Correct. The brush-border cells of the small intestine lining do not produce any protein digestive enzymes, although they do produce enterokinase, an enzyme necessary to activate the trypsinogen enzyme from the pancreas in the small intestine.
